Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2011 11:56AM scuttlers wrote: I contacted the Insurance company directly via phone and asked for the Accelerated benefits application.  They sent me the wrong forms the first time (sent forms to apply for insurance).  I called back and stated "I have breast cancer, Stage IV, I need the forms for Accelerated benefits".  When I got the forms, I filled them out stating simply that "patient will be on chemo for the rest of her life".  I took the physician form to my oncologist and requested respectfully that he agree "less than 6-12 months is anticipated survival".  He understood (after I asked him to "guarantee" that I would have a longer life span in writing).  The physician form had to be mailed from the office.  My forms, I sent by fax and by snail mail.  The company called me and asked several questions, the main one being that I had been working full time when the insurance was originally implemented, which I was.  (This was because the insurance was through my employer and it stipulated that I had to be working full time at the time I applied for the original policy for it to be in effect.)  Received the check about two weeks later.  They kept $5,000 in reserve and covered, so my DH will get that when the time comes.

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2012 07:11AM scuttlers wrote: My DH was on Levoquin several years ago. He rapidly progressed to "Stevens Johnsons Syndrome" when he started taking it. What a nightmare! He was taken by ambulance to Stanford and stayed there almost a week. It took over 5 months for his skin to recover, (and God knows what was happening inside). His skin peeled off in ugly sheets for weeks. If taking Levoquin - keep a close eye on ANY new or different side effects. (his side effects started as blisters/hives, progressed rapidly and within hours he was confused and very tired.)

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2012 07:45AM scuttlers wrote: Anne, my DH did have a terrible infection on his leg. It was nasty, and nothing was helping. (this was not a cold or a cough). It was very visual, and definitely an infection. He is not one to see doctors for anything, he thinks the body will heal itself for most issues. (in fact, I think that in 20 years he has seen a doctor for 3 issues in all). I feel, that in my humble opion, you are placing some of the blame for these antibiotic side effects on us. This is so very far from the truth. I nearly lost my DH because of the Levoquin reaction and because the medical personnel at the 3 different ER's I drove him to that night could not recognized the situation. He was covered with hives, could barely walk, and was incoherent by the time we reached the third ER and the doctor was standing by the front desk. This doctor had seen this before! He had DH in an ambulance on the way to Stanford within minutes. He knew this was life or death and that minutes count. DO NOT place the blame on overuse of antibiotics on the patients! (and for the previous posters, this is definitely and totally NOT the problem). The overuse of antibiotics is another issue, and lands right in the hands and control of the prescribing medical PROFESSIONAL.

Posts.Content: Apr 13, 2011 09:59AM - edited Apr 13, 2011 11:48AM by scuttlers The link is:  www.mutualdirect.com/sal I sent a request for information, received information in the mail.  I filled the form out and sent it back with a check for the first month ($37.50) on March 11, 2011.  MofO called and asked several question, including information about the cancer.  I told her that I was Stage IV, IBC, date of diagnosis (fairly simple questions, no lab reports to send etc.). Received the policy towards the end of March with approval.  If death occurs in the first two years - it pays back the premiums that I paid in plus 10%.  (Where else can you get 10% guaranteed return nowadays?  I am looking at this as a savings account for the first two years.)  After two years it pays the $10,000 - up to my 100th birthday (we can wish).   I just noticed that it is guaranteed for ages 45+.  Wouldn't hurt to give them a call and see if they insure "younger" ladies.  Hope this helps.

Posts.Content: scuttlers wrote: Thought I might post this just in case anyone else is making frequent trips to MD Anderson and needs to watch every penny spent as we do. I got on the wrong bus by accident one day.  The Airport Express #102 boards outside Terminal C at IAH. (NOT the Airport Direct which is $15.00+ each way.)  It is $1.25 to the Metro Rail and takes about an hour.  Then walk across the street and take the Metro Rail for another $1.25 to the hospital.  To return just reverse the process.  The bus is very comfortable, tour type - not the city transit type.  Just don't have a lot of luggage, I only take a carry on. I usually stay at Rotary House, and use the Marriott as second if they are full.  Give your patient number and they give a nice discount (Marriott).  You must be a patient to stay at Rotary. Hope this helps someone, wish I had known this earlier.  Sherrie  My favorite side effect of treatments is BEING ALIVE! Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2010 09:00AM scuttlers wrote: Since last November when I contacted them after the Nevada docs told me to "go home and spend time with your family, there is nothing more we can do"; I have gone to Houston 9 times.   Most trips are two days.  First day scans and tests, second day meet with doctors, boards, etc. and review treatment options.  Then meet with main onc there and have a telephone conference with onc here to make sure treatment is on board to be done here.  (If I have to have any more radiation, I will have it done in Houston.)   I catch the "red eye" down (leaves at 1AM), sleep on the flight, catch the bus to the medical center, have tests for about 10+ hours (more sleep time), check into Rotary house, meet the docs the next morning, and catch the 3PM flight back.   I may be looking at stem cell in the future.  MD Anderson or Seattle Care Alliance would be my choices if this comes to be.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 02:31AM scuttlers wrote: There is no good thing about breast cancer. Herceptin is a great drug, when it is effective and works. I progressed on Herceptin. Several times. Combined other drugs to it and have had success in getting back to NED several times. I believe the key for me is catching progression earlier and making changes to stop the progression from becoming problems. NED, also known as no evidence of disease, does not mean "cure" (as my family thinks). I have to explain this to them each time I progress. I get the, "but I thought you were NED, I thought you were cured.". NED means that we have been successful in knocking the cancer down to where it can not be seen by the scans. So we continue to scan every 3-6 months until it can be seen again. And then we change the chemo cocktails until NED is once again achieved. Have always kept the Herceptin in the mix. Added Tykerb, which will also always be kept in the mix. Currently getting Ixempra with the mix which has been successful in knocking back the cancer enough that it can not be seen on the scans currently.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2013 04:30PM scuttlers wrote: Hi everyone! I am Sherrie, 59 years old, married to my high school sweetheart. Three children - son in Las Vegas, daughter in Portland, OR, and daughter in Boston area, MA. Grandchildren are 21, 14, 9, and 7. A great who is 2. My DH found me 20 years ago, and we married. It has been truly a magical life. We traveled the US in a motor coach for 17 years, full time. He worked in major commercial construction, I worked in surgery. We were able to see, visit, and experience 49 states! We stopped traveling and settled in Las Vegas where I was offered my dream job. Designing, implementing, and teaching a Surgical Technology Program at the college level. It was absolutely everything I had ever dreamed of. WHAM! On February 4th 2009, I was notified that I had Inflammatory Breast Cancer. I had never heard of this, but "believed" the hype of the pink ribbon. I fought hard (with positive attitude) through the chemo, had the BMX (so I wouldn't have to worry about the other breast), went through the rads. Changed my diet, juiced, exercised, all that jazz. Working, smiling, laughing - all the hoopla that is spread far and wide with the wonderful "runs for the ...". The week before Thanksgiving I got the results of my "treatment" followup PET scan. It was spreading, fast, the onc did not know what to do to stop it, go home and gather those you love - you will not live past Christmas. I went home and sent an email to MD Anderson begging for help. Within an hour (this was late in the evening), I received a call from a nurse there. YES, we can help you - magical words to my ears. You have to be here on Monday - it was Thursday, and we were flat out broke! I called my family, and took my car down for a title loan and scraped together enough money to get there. Within 3 days we had a plan. The team was amazing. Yes, Sherrie, you are going to die from IBC, No, it is NOT going to be this year. I go every 3 months, get fully checked, and am given plans to choose from. Then I come home for treatments. I came to BCO needing help tolerating some of the treatment. Bless these people, they got me through that time, and many times since then. You are my lifeline, my friends, my angels, my group. We basically gave away our home in Vegas (another story, another time) and bought a home back "home" in Idaho, where we went to high school, where we fell in love, where we have family. Thanks to BCO I knew to cash in my life insurance, apply for STD then LTD, and SSDI. We live a comfortable life in a house built in 1917. No mortgage, no payments, just life. I quickly learned the realities of breast cancer, in these four years. I believe in the beginning most of us go through the "5 stages of grief". It is necessary. Now I am in acceptance, and can really live life every day. I am no longer afraid or frightened. I no longer believe I can control this with diet, juices, or more. I know that I can live life to the fullest. I grieve when we lose our members to this horrid disease. But I am also very blessed and happy that I "knew" them and that I could call them my friends. BCO is very much a part of my therapy, my living, my sanity. I AM HERE. I AM ALIVE! I love every day. I love life.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2012 10:13PM scuttlers wrote: Take a long deep breath. Sounds like your mom has had good care! Tumor markers (also known as CA 15-3 etc.) are not always reliable in diagnosis. This is the reason she is going to have a PET scan. Many here on the boards have numbers in the hundreds, a few in the thousands. There is a lot of information the doctor will be obtaining (PET, blood tests, etc.) and then a treatment plan will be presented depending on the results. So right now, just breath and give your mom love, she certainly doesn't need her daughter to "be a basket case and worried sick and crying all the time". Wait for the results, get a plan, and let us know how she (and you) are doing.

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2011 04:23PM scuttlers wrote: We buried my BIL last week. My DH and I basically begged him in July to accept a second opinion and get effective treatment. His DIL (a doctor) spoke with him in September, and came to us in tears to see if we could speak with him again. His cancer type has a 2% mortality, 98% survive with proper treatment. Two weeks before he died, he changed his mind and was then ready to do whatever was necessary. It was too late. I had to let go of my anger that he wouldn't fight and just love him and be there to hold his hand through those horrid last two weeks. It was hard, but it was HIS decision to make, not mine - not his grand children, not his brothers, not his dear wife, or all the others that loved him so. It is a persons right to choose. This choice should not be based on fear. Knowledge is very important. I do not regret the choices I made. It was not an easy road, and I'm aware it will have some rough times ahead. Another day, another week, another year to see my grand children to laugh with my husband - it is worth it all. You may have to just be there with and for her. Love her though, whatever her decision is - it is hers to make. Don't make every last moment and memory an argument. It was hard to do for my BIL, but we did have some good memories as a family in the last few months that will be cherished.

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2011 02:08PM scuttlers wrote: shevawn wrote: "My onc told me that I am considered "cured" and cancer-free from the date of my surgery, which was only 7 days after I was diagnosed. That's pretty remarkable, right?!? She also told me that breast cancer can be considered cured after it's treated - the first time you have it. (or, in the rare instance of a second, completely different cancer) However, once it recurs, it will likely kill you and it is becomes impossible to cure. At that point, you can only manage the disease, like diabetes.   I understand the aversion to words like "cure," but I am equally averse to scaring women to death & letting them think that breast cancer is a death sentence, because it's clearly not anymore. Lots of women avoid screenings because they're afraid of being told they have cancer, which they think means they're going to lose their hair, puke all the time & die a horrible, painful death. If we can portray an accurate picture of BC treatment, that's not all pink ribbons & rainbows nor is it death & suffering, we'll all be better for it. " Shevawn - thank you for clarifying and for the apology. None of us meant to say that Stage I is less worthy. We were amazed that someone would post a cure seven days after diagnosis on a Stage IV Metastatic Forum. It seems very cruel, and I for one as others have stated have been really bothered by this statement. Also the statement that breast cancer is clearly not a death sentence anymore. For us, it is! It has caused unbelieveable pain (physical and mental), it has wrecked havoc with our lives. We are not nor will we ever be "better for it". Everyone of us hope sincerely that you are never in our shoes. You are so beautiful, so young, so needed by your son, so alive! What we want is for you and the rest of the world to understand that although awareness and early detection is happening - WE NEED A CURE, WE NEED IT NOW, too many are dying!!!! Personally, I feel your onc was wrong to tell you that you were cured by your surgery. And evidently, you did not believe this as fact, as you have gone on to have chemo, radiation, and hormone treatment. Many of us have cashed our life insurance policies (even the insurance companies understand we are dying), we are trying to live on disability as we can no longer work due to the side effects of our treatments and the limitations that breast cancer has brought to our lives. We are thankful for good days, we rejoice when we find another treatment that is working and we fight hard to endure the side effects of those treatments in order to gain another month, another year, with our loved ones. We would NEVER want any new members to "this club"; but we are here together to help each other through. We celebrate the little things together, we cry together, and we try to endure and hold each other up. We do want to let the people out there know that breast cancer is not pretty pink ribbons. It is hard when the popular thing is to cover up this reality. When even young women (such as yourself) believe this can be beat, that it is something that will make us a better person (there was nothing wrong with the person I was, I want her back), that pink ribboned parades and celebrations are helping. We want the millions to go to actually finding a cure and not into the pockets of corporations to make them richer. Many of us were there where you are, thinking that this was actually a fight that could be won. Until reality came crashing down. Now we can barely get through our children's birthdays and milestones without crying because we know it may be the last one we get to celebrate. Our lives are lived in 3 month periods, plans can be made for 3 months, then the scans and tests, if they are good, we can plan another 12 weeks. Somedays happiness is being able to make a meal, somedays it is simply being able to take a shower without crying for help, or making it to the bathroom in time. Not pretty, not pink, no amount of awareness running is going to remove this reality of what breast cancer truly is. You were not dismissed because of your Stage, we were shocked that you would make the comments on a Stage IV forum. The message did read as if you believed the oncologist. It angered us that an oncologist would say such an untruth. And it angers us that so many believe the propaganda, and do not know the reality. You are more than welcome here. No one has asked that you not be here, we do ask that you be sensitive to where we are in this journey.

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2011 08:49AM scuttlers wrote: Definitely a great idea. I went two years ago (when my local oncologist sent me home to "get my affairs in order and be with family"). I told him I was going and asked if he would be willing to work with them. I flew down every 3 months for the first year. One full (and very efficient) day of testing and met with the doctors the next day. They always gave options. We decided which to do, the oncologist would call my local one while we were there and discuss our decision. THEY SAVED MY LIFE! Got me on meds that were only in trial (on compassionate care). Got me to NED in 6 months! After a year I went to 6 month followups there. (Still getting treatments at home.). And last Thusday had the workup at MDA. Still NED! Definitely a great idea.

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2011 07:38AM scuttlers wrote: The problem with waiting is that it could be possible that the insurance could not be changed in time. (you do not want to wait for an accident to get car insurance). It is good to be proactive in thinking of insurance coverage. Yes, you may go years at Stage III; it can not be guaranteed. Switching now may be tight financially, but would give peace of mind. And the same goes for the life insurance and disability insurance. Get it BEFORE you need it. There are so many out there that do not have this option. You are protecting your family and your little ones future. Best of wishes for you and family.

Posts.Content: scuttlers wrote: I have not posted in a long time. The loss of so many friends here this year has devastated me. Especially the ones I was able to spend precious time with, laughing, going to dinner, shopping, etc.  they left a huge hole in my life.  As some of the "old timers" here know (there are so many new names),  my dearest brother was diagnosed with. Stage IV lymphoma two weeks before my diagnosis with Stage IV IBC. He and I are extremely close.  In age and in our life, so many horrid and terrible experiences during our precious childhood. He is just one year younger than I am, but always took the BIG brother/protector role.  I am headed to Seattle this morning. He had his third stem cell transplant about 45 days ago and is in the midst of graft versus host disease. They believe his stomach has been destroyed by the implanted cells.  He has lost at least 80 pounds. Last week, I was caregiver for 10 days and he asked me to shave him. He looked like a skeleton. I had to take extra Ativan to keep from sobbing!  Dad came up and took over for me, for what was to be two weeks. He called several times a day, and the last couple of days has cried a lot. I decided to go up early to help support dad. My other brother was going to come up on Sunday for a 24 hour visit. When he found out that I was going early, he hopped on a flight last night. Dad and him are like oil and water, and volatile. Last time this brother visited dad (who is 80 and just had quad bypass in the last year), dad called me crying and said "come quick sissy, I need help".  It took me hours to get him stable enough to smile again.  My DB is going in for exploratory surgery today. No immune system. Weak as a baby. But the docs need to know how much damage has been done. I wanted to be there to hold dad so he didn't have to face this alone.  Other brother called mom, got her totally upset, and she has been calling constantly and wants to come up. Hate to say it but she is the total definition of narcissistic and truly can't be handled when someone else is needing comfort - such as dying DB, devastated dad, and controlling other brother.  UGH!  I met with the onc yesterday, spoke with the clinic mental health worker. I am armed with good drugs. But wow, I don't need this right now.  I go to MDA in two weeks for scheduled scans. Can't even think that far ahead. This is just too much!!! So that is why I've been hanging out here on the edges, and not posting. Miss you all.  Sorry welcomes to all the newbies. Sorry goodbyes to all the friends who are no longer here. I think I need you all right now really bad. Thanks for listening.  My favorite side effect of treatments is BEING ALIVE! Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2013 04:49AM scuttlers wrote: The key is to check the "out of pocket maximum". Once you reach that (which will be very very quickly), the insurance should pay 100%. I know $527 premiums seem high, mine were $1289 for the last 2 years. UGH! finally going on Medicare next month. YEAH! (I hope). My current "deductible" on my primary insurance is 10,900. Then the coverage is 50/50 for out of area (most know I go to MDA, which is way out of area). My premium is $657 for that one alone. I have a secondary coverage which is also being COBRAed, bringing our COBRA payments up to 1289 per month. Luckily the two insurances have fiscal years six months apart. Somehow it works that the high deductible is paid by the secondary insurance, and then by the time a deductible is due on the secondary, the primary insurance covers it. The key though is what is the "out of pocket maximum". I meet mine within the first few weeks due to the extensive treatment and costs. I did find out that travel is covered and part of hotels. (I was totally shocked to find this tucked into the 178 page "master plan". You may want to get a copy of the master plan and study it. They even pay me mileage for the trips to and from the infusion clinic AND for driving to the drug store to pick up scripts. Saw an ad in the December issue of Woman's Day in the doctors office today, that said Susan Komen Foundation paid for some ladies' medical care for several years through a grant. Full page ad, would like to see how to apply and get one of those grants.

Posts.Content: May 1, 2013 06:01AM scuttlers wrote: Don't know where you are located. Most oncology centers in the US have a "Patient's Bill of Rights", it is usually posted in the rooms, but you may need to ask for it. It includes control of pain. I would write out what the issues are in numerical order and go through them one by one. 1. I insist on quality of life, that includes control of my pain. Are you willing to work with me in this issue? 2. I insist that I understand the treatments (including medications to control/manage side effects). Are you willing to answer my questions until I understand your reasoning for the drugs we are using/going to use? These are examples. I write out exactly what I want to discuss with my oncologist every time I go in. He has come to expect it and seems to appreciate the outline and thoroughness. I have no need for an oncologist who has an ego. He knows that. (I interviewed several when I moved to find one who would work with me and with MDA to give me the type of life that I want. In other words, if this jerk won't come around - especially after a straight forward discussion as to your expectations - then you need to find one who will. I do not deal with a PCP. I have enough appointments without throwing another doctor into the mix. I insist that my oncologist manage ALL my prescriptions. I told him that I do not want to be running from doctor to doctor to get prescriptions. And the final decisions are MINE not his to make. If I need anxiety meds, I let him know. If I need pain control, I let him know. If I need something to help with my libido, I let him know. Find an oncologist that puts you back in control of your healthcare - it will relieve a ton of stress!

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 05:03AM scuttlers wrote: Had my Power Port put in at 6AM, done by 6:45, back in the classroom teaching at 7. Very minimal pain. Did not need pain medication. Although teaching college age super motivated students is endorphin producing (IMHO). Have never needed any numbing medication. I make sure they scrub the site gently for the appropriate amount of time to prevent infection. And then follow sterile technique to access. (wash hands, sterile gloves, do not touch the port without sterile gloves, etc.). I tell them to just do it, no count down. Never any pain whatsoever. And I also make sure they follow the correct procedure to flush it at the end. Have had the Power Port for 3.5 years and it is working strong. As for accessing for PET or other scans, it depends on if the tech has been trained and certified to access. That is why some can not access the port for the infusion. You can go to the chemo unit and get a nurse who is trained, but sometimes that is a hassle. I do it here at my home town unit because they always draw blood before any infusion or PET injection. I go to the chemo unit and ask them to leave it in until infusion time. At MDA, if I have lots of tests scheduled, I ask that my fist stop be on the chemo floor for port access, then leave it in all day for the other tests. My port is my second best friend, DH is my best!

Posts.Content: Mar 3, 2011 10:29AM - edited Mar 3, 2011 10:30AM by scuttlers DH's can do bonehead things, especially when they feel extreme helplessness to make us better. You do not say how long you have been married. Perhaps you might suggest to him to seek his " counsel" from a professional. A lot of men do not want to admit they can use the counseling, they think it makes them less of a man. A situation like yours can be a catalyst to get them there. A lot of us who have had our partner's actions hurt and disappoint. If you want it; this can be navigated with minimal damage to the relationship. And even can, in some situations make it stronger and provide him with ways to truly help the entire family through. It sounds like he understands the damage and loves you; is he willing to go the distance with you? Are you willing to go the distance with him. In my situation, just a couple of sessions with a professional brought things around. I would go right back into cousel in a heart beat if I felt the need to (in myself or DH).

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2011 04:22PM scuttlers wrote: Don't read the stats! Most are outdated and there are great treatments coming our way each year. You have come to a great place for information and support. Or if you read the stats (we all do, I think) put them into perspective and their proper place. Mine said 30% survival at 18 months - so I told myself that SOMEONE had to be in that group for it to exist, and I was going to be in that group. In just the last 3 years there have been tremendous advances. With IBC, I would highly suggest a consult with the "experts" if you can. MD Anderson is truly making cancer history. You really need to be in charge and on top of your treatments. Sorry you have joined the "club", it is not an easy journey. My first treatments were the TCH (yours) and in 2.5 months it will be THREE years! Of those 3 years, the last 19 months - NED! Also, you can check into SSDI (IBC is listed as compassionate allowance), accelerated payout on life insurance, long term disability (if you are working and this is in your benefits). Etc. All you can do to remove stress and be able to focus on healing and knocking CA's butt will help! PM me if you wish. Best of luck, but more than that - LIVE!

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 10:46AM scuttlers wrote: My high school sweetheart called me one Thursday night 20 years AFTER graduation, and said, "you don't have to answer today, I'll call back on Saturday for your answer, I have loved you forever and I always will, so will you please come home and marry me?". OMG, did that ever rock my boat! I told everyone at work (I was on a surgical heart team) and they discussed this, took a vote and unanimously said go for it. When he called me back, I said, "if you want me, come and get me". He said, "what is the closest airport, I'll be there next Saturday". And he was. We had not set eyes on each other for 20 years. We got married six days later. We celebrate our 20 anniversary this year! Not one day have I regretted having my best friend by my side. Especially now, here on this part of the journey of life. He is my rock. I want to be in his arms, looking into his eyes when that final day comes. It would be a shame for him to have loved so deeply, and to be locked on the outside, and not be there. Yes, it will hurt but the memories of what we have will get him through. Your weekend sounds incredible! Make more of those memories, especially for him. Don't lock love out on the outside looking in. Don't let cancer take that love, caring, joy, away! If we had only had one day, one month, one year of that perfect being together - it would have still been worth it.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2013 04:24AM scuttlers wrote: Perhaps your DS has spent time with Dr. Google and is scared. He probably feels like he is lying, you raised him well! Explain to him that you ARE OK. Your last scans were great. There are many treatments to come, and they may work for years. He needs to hear this from you. Three years ago, I was told that I would not live through Christmas. I was in my first year, it was heartbreaking to friends and family. My children came to spend time with me. My brothers and sisters and mom and dad came. My friends came from far away places. Then I found a team that was more positive and gave me options, real options that worked! It is awkward to be doing OK (back to NED once again a couple of weeks ago) and to have them question how I am. Yes, I have advanced cancer. But I am doing OK. Sometimes I wonder if they think I over exaggerated 3 years ago. My DH needed an outlet to be able to talk and I let him know it was OK to talk, with some exceptions. Such as neighbors who I have contact with often. It has helped him to be able to clear his mind. And it helps me to be able to converse with daily contacts without the cancer being a topic. He needs to know you are OK, really and honestly OK. He also needs to be able to share his concerns with maybe his close friends. I am sure that you have let him know that if your condition changes, you will be honest and straight with him.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 11:03PM scuttlers wrote: Cool breeze, I applied for FMLA, calculated my available sick time accrued, and worked 4 hours per week for the 12 weeks FMLA. This gave me a full paycheck. The first week of FMLA, I filed for SSDI, STD, LTD, and accelerated death benefits. ALL were approved (through compassionate care allowance) within 10 days of applications being filed! Yes, I was approved for SSDI and started the waiting period while on FMLA and drawing a full paycheck on my sick time accrued. The doc stipulated that I was NOT to work more than 4 hours per week. I turned in all my scans, reports, the whole HUGE file the day I turned in the SSDI application. I did on-line and took hard copy to the local office. Cool breeze, the benefits you receive for Stage IV from the employer will not count against being approved for SSDI. File SSDI immediately and get those benefits started as soon as possible. The benefits from the employer are benefits not earned income. My STD, LTD, and death benefits payments had no impact on the timing or the amount of SSDI. The important thing is to file ALL BEFORE losing employment. (which nixes the thought that you must not be working to qualify). If you are no longer employed, you are probably not cover by those benefits anymore. (I contacted the insurance company directly to get this information, HR told me to wait until after I was not working which would have disqualified the STD, LTD, and Death Benefits.)
Posts.Title: disability Lauriesh JillThut

Posts.Content: May 17, 2012 10:01PM scuttlers wrote: Yes Coolbreeze, the money is a BENEFIT and NOT earned income. It will not affect the start of and payment for SSDI. It doesn't matter that it matches your salary. As for accelerated benefits the doctor has to sign of that you are expected to die within a certain period of time. It is kind of hard to get this in writing but just ignore the emotional impact. It is the check in hand that matters. My doc kind of baulked but I told him to sign the paper or give me an absolute guarantee IN WRITING that I would positively live longer. He signed. I just called the insurance and asked them to send the paperwork for Accelerated Benefits. (remember, if you don't take advantage of the accelerated benefits now, you will lose them completely once you are no longer an employee.)

Posts.Content: May 17, 2012 10:10PM scuttlers wrote: STD - short term disability LTD - long term disability Death Benefits - most employers especially state employer have life insurance benefits for the employee Any benefits that are connected to your employer - i. e. Short term disability, long term disability, life insurance, cancer insurance benefit, etc. MUST be applied for BEFORE ending your employment. Once employment ends, you are no longer eligible for those benefits. Contact your insurance company (who carries the insurance) and ask them for complete policies and application paperwork. I found that human resources was clueless and I would have lost all these benefits if I had done as they instructed. As for filing SSDI, that is not tied to your current position of being employed, so can be filed after you are no longer employed.

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2012 02:37AM - edited Mar 16, 2012 02:51AM by scuttlers This could be a hard decision.  For me, it would be a simple no, and here are the reasons. When I was first diagnosed, everyone at work knew.  And it sucked, because the entire dynamics of how I was treated changed.  I absolutely hated that every conversation, every passing in the hallway, every luncheon was interjected with the dreaded "how are you?", "are you cured", "my aunt/neighbor/sister ...", you all know the drill.  I just wanted to be me, doing me job.   I would question as to why is HR doing this.  What is the purpose?  What do they expect to accomplish.  And the simple fact that they say  "This new project will have a video portion that will focus on people who have been put in difficult situations and yet have "stayed the course" so to speak and are doing ok now", kind of makes me feel they don't understand MBC at all.  The other examples you give can be compartmentalized and left behind (although the emotional impact for life would be life altering).  MBC can not be left behind, so to say, it is here, it is here to stay.  One moment the entire situation can change and the beast can kill.  It is a constant.  It is NOT an adversary that was overcome, moved on, and now are OK.  Can MBC be explained in a few minutes of a video that has the purpose of showing you "are doing OK now"?   Would the reality of MBC be shown? Since that is not the purpose of the video, I would doubt that would be the message that they are trying to disseminate.   And if the reality of MBC is not going to be shown, then really what would be the purpose?  (It would be interesting to know what your company does, makes me wonder why they are doing this project?) We can compare to Pandora's Box.    When we moved back home to Idaho, I became very careful on who was given information regarding my condition.  NONE of my neighbors know.  Someday they will, not today.  Today I want the neighborhood to be blissfully unaware so I can enjoy the BBQ's and other gatherings without being the cancer girl.  My father is a long standing and very influential member of Rotary. He took me for several months, and wanted me to join.  Then one day, one of the women there who was friends with my Mom, let the cat out of the bag.  So each meeting someone who ask the dreaded questions.  It totally ruined the experience of being in a philantrophy group and being able to offer my talents as an intelligent, working, individual.  It sucked.   I agree that we need to get the word and knowledge out to the public on the realities of BC and especially the realities of MBC.  Would this project be able to do this?  They are probably aiming for showing you as a smiling, happy, functional, intelligent etc. individual who has not let MBC control your life.  Are they going to show what the reality is?  Probably NOT, because that is not the purpose of the project.   And on a personal note,  I agree with kschultz, "when everyone in the office becomes aware of your situation, they you WILL be seen differently and treated differently". (Edited to attempt to rid the changing italics and fonts that showed up in the original post.)

Both were approved the following week. The carriers told me that if she had waited until I was no longer working, I would not have been covered. Did you sign anything starting the process before quitting? If so, you may be able to get an attorney to help. Or was it that HR never did put you on the policies and premiums were not paid? Sorry, (and you do not have to answer the questions). HR can be totally clueless. As for continuing to work or not - decide what is really important as to how you spend your time and your heart will lead you.

Posts.Content: Feb 29, 2012 11:47PM - edited Feb 29, 2012 11:49PM by scuttlers KNOCK IT OFF!!!!  (sorry, but that is what you asked for) ... Seriously, the port is your friend.  I am surprised you did not get one before.  (Mine was put in 2 days after diagnosis, THREE YEARS ago.)  I absolutely HATE the poking for the IV's, and would only give the nurse 2 pokes before she had to get someone else...   I would say my port has been used 150+ times, saving my veins and protecting my arms from the dreaded lymphodema.  I tell the nurse, just do it, don't "count down", don't tell me, just do it - and I truly don't feel a thing!   Come on!  YOU HAVE TIGER BLOOD!  GET OVER IT and enjoy those twilight drugs tomorrow! edited to add:  Ask for a Power Port!  Then the scan stuff can be infused, blood draws for labs, etc.  When I go to MDA, I get stuck ONE TIME, they leave the access in for the whole day - all the scans, all the blood draws, LOVE IT, LOVE IT, LOVE IT!

Posts.Content: scuttlers wrote: One of the members suggested that I post to the Stage IV forum, so here I am.  I was Stage III at diagnosis in early 2009; have had recurrence to neck including vascular infiltration so may be Stage IV - haven't asked, kind of afraid to.   I know this is my first post here, and I just don't feel like taking the energy or the time to "introduce" and "get to know".  Forgive me, after 18 months of hell, I don't have much left for niceties.  Since February this year, the oncologist has prescribed Tykerb.  I continue to work full time, as I have since the beginning - but this drugs is kicking my butt big time!   Back to the hard decision on the Tykerb. I have had nothing but problems with this drug.  I begged the oncologist to stop it and they ask me why would I consider stopping a drug that is keeping me alive.  The last two sets of scans show no evidence of progression and no evidence of disease.   (April and June; another set will be done in September). The Tykerb is worse than any of the sets of chemo I went through.  So tired, pain, nausea (vomiting in the AM), constant diarrhea, mouth sores, nasal sores, hair falling out, dizzy, vertigo, and basically a loss of will to do anything while taking the drug.  I truly feel that I can not live the rest of my life like that.  I stop it, and within 24 hours I feel better, no dizziness, no nausea, and I feel like smiling again.   Like I said, the doctors insist I continue the drug.  They tell me that if I don't the cancer will progress and it would be basically a miracle if I make it through the year.  (I feel that it is a miracle that I am showing NED at this stage!)  They tell me that if I continue it, my survival could well be up to 10 years or more.  But it is absolutely worse than any of the chemo infusions - I knew that I would feel better the next day or the next week on them.  With the Tykerb, I will never feel better.  The doctors also tell me that I should continue this drug until it stops working - so there is no end in sight. I took it for a week to start, stopped because of this.  Tried again at a lower dose for a couple of weeks, and stopped again.  This cycle has been on and off since February.   When I take the Tykerb, the side effects are immediate - the very next day.  As the days continue, the effects become more and more difficult to deal with and seem to escalate.  Each night, when taking this drug, I feel as if I am taking poison!  I stopped again last night, I couldn't bring myself to swallow the pills.  This morning - no dizziness, no headache, I feel like smiling, and my energy has returned.  Best of all my will to get up and "live" has returned.    Any ideas of how to handle the side effects?  Has anyone taken this for an extended period of time and had the symptoms start to even out or become more bearable?  My favorite side effect of treatments is BEING ALIVE! Dx 2/4/2009, IBC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 3, 11/17 nodes, mets, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2010 04:37PM scuttlers wrote: THANK YOU ALL for the support and the information!  I did start back on the Tykerb, and with your help have reduced the side effects considerably.   Changes were:  take in the AM (rather than PM), cut out all sugar and most carbs from the diet, drinking massive amounts of water, and cut out all the other prescription pills.   So far the side effects are currently:  slight headache in the morning, diarrhea is only 1-2 times a day, dizziness and vertigo only when changing position too rapidly.  I am having some difficulty sleeping, insomnia etc. but will try to get this controlled utilizing tapes and relaxation rather than medication.  I CAN LIVE WITH THIS! Every muscle in my body is hurting, and I am having some intense spasms - BUT we have been laying ceramic tile in the sewing room, laundry, hall, and kitchen - and I believe these are from the exertion from the project and NOT from the drug.  (And the floor is looking GOOD!)  Again I thank you!

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 07:17PM scuttlers wrote: It really hurts when loved ones have this in their minds and believe it. My DH was of this mind set for the first 10 months, until the oncologist in Houston very emphatically told me, "you are going to die from breast cancer" with him in the room. He was totally shocked that it was actually fatal! And I will say, I love that oncologist, she got me to NED within 6 months of that conversation. The cancer had invaded my jugular, she fought for surgery, she fought for very agressive chemo, and she is the reason I am alive today. My daughters refuse to discuss the "cancer", and do not understand why I am still taking treatments. They are both in the medical field, as was I, and neither comprehend Stage IV. They think I am a drama queen and exaggerate. Both have been very hurtful in their comments in the last few years and basically have said they think I should stop treatment and get on with "it". My mom just asked me yesterday why on earth am I still going to MDA, why are you still having scans done, and WHY are you still having infusions and taking oral chemo. UGH!!!! Too many think there is actually a cure. I had no idea when I was diagnosed what the new normal would be. I actually thought OK, some chemo, surgery, chemo, and radiation and I'll be "good to go". Quite an education in the last 3 years. Time for the "pink fluff" to stop. Time for a CURE. Time for honesty. This is NOT pretty, it is NOT how I wanted to spend the rest of my life, it has NOT "made me better". I HATE CANCER. I also hate that the majority of people do not know the truth.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 06:32PM scuttlers wrote: Not necessarily so, a small lesion on a bone (or several) is easier to radiate and stop from progressing than to wait until the lesion grows and causes a broken bone or nerve impingement/nerve damage which is more difficult to treat and get good results. Floating down denial river is gentle and comforting to many of us, I spend a lot of time on that boat. Then I face the realities, get busy with understanding that knowledge can give me power and face the fears headon. Currently had recent progression after 2+ years of NED. Scan showed cancer was moving up the right neck via the vascular system straight towards the head (that is where I keep my brain). We decided to jump on this with some big guns (which has been pure hell for the last 6 weeks, and I was ready to quit.). Scanned again, and showed "complete metabolic response" to the current chemo. Ok, so I guess it will be worth it to finish the next four cycles of this crap to stay in NED's arms for a possible couple more years. No symptoms, just a scan that showed the progression. Know your enemy, know where it is, know what it is doing. I would rathe have the 6 chemo sessions (which are truly difficult), than be fighting brain Metz, which is where this would have gone. All without symptoms.

Posts.Content: May 17, 2012 11:03AM scuttlers wrote: You can file your application (especially utilizing compassionate care allowance), at any time. You do not have to wait until you have not worked for 4-5-6 months. I actually filed before I quit working and was approved within 10 days. Of course I still had my waiting period, but the checks were deposited automatically right on time. I drew my last full paycheck (using up my sick time accrued) in December of that year, STD check was deposited in January, SSDI was deposited in April, and LTD was deposited in May. Continue on the SSDI and LTD. I took FMLA and immediately filed all the applications. This gave me 12 weeks to get all approved and in motion. If there had been gliches, I could have returned to my position (which was protected by the FMLA). I was the only bread earner at that time and it was mandatory to have income without a break. As a side note, LTD sent me a letter about 6 weeks ago telling me that I would "run out" of benefits in the following year. I immediately sent them a letter with a full copy of my policy showing that my benefits DID NOT have a set time restriction. They called me the following week and apologized and sent an apology letter in the mail stating that my benefits did not have this expiration time. You really have to keep on top of these people and stand you ground and most important understand your policies.
Posts.Title: disability Lauriesh JillThut

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 06:50AM scuttlers wrote: Coolbreeze, find out who the life insurance is carried through. Call them directly, tell them you need a full copy of the policy (it may be available on line), and also you need the forms to file for Accelerated Benefits. (if the person you talk to doesn't know about Accelerated Benefits, don't worry, it will be detailed in the policy and that will be your guide). Do not lose this benefit. Most life insurance policies allow 50-80% pay out on accelerated benefits. Doctors form showing expected death within a certain period of time. (heck, you've had these expected outcomes several times in the last year - c diff etc.). The payout is NOT taxed, tax free. And usually once the payout is made, the insurance company will waive the future premiums and the remainder of the insurance will remain in effect until you actually die. As I said, this must be done before you are not an employee and before you lose the benefit.

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2016 10:14PM scuttlers wrote: Wow, I don't know if I am reading this correctly, but I would be devastated if DH told me to stay off everything and not take anything anymore. He has been my constant cheerleader though 7+ years. "You can do one more day" "just another hour honey" "you can do this". "I am here, let me help". Yes, there were horrid times. All in all so far - 18+ months total of HARD chemos. Not all in a row, reoccurrence was twice. And radiation. And of course the orals - arimedex, Tykerb, Xeloda, Letrozole, etc. and five major surgeries. And a clinical trial and Herceptin infusions EVERY three weeks for 7 years and 10 months. BUT we have made it to now. Which is almost four years of no evidence of disease. Yes, there was a toll to pay. I move slow. I sleep a lot. I have aches and pains and head aches. I feel old, and thanks to the treatments, I am getting older! I laugh, cry, enjoy, love, and live life to the fullest I can. I could NOT have done that without support from family, and I hope that is not where you are right now. I did take this past summer off everything except the Herceptin. It was a fantastic summer. Back on, nose to the grindstone as they say. My daughter told me way back in the beginning - why don't you just die already? Ugh, couldn't believe I had actually raised someone so self centered and without empathy. Another story, another time. Not pertinent. What is, is that THIS is your decision. Itis easier with support, and I hope I am reading wrong. Personally, I like living, even with the side effects.

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2011 12:31PM scuttlers wrote: Definitely sounds liken allergic reaction and not to be taken lightly! As the others have said, get medical attention to this before taking any more. Started Tykerb in April 2010, 20 months now, and it was this forum that got me through so I could tolerate it. (Now, I take it in the MIDDLE of the night, go back to sleep for a few hours. Really has helped with the SE.) Has ANYONE noticed that the SE change when you start a new bottle? Some months I have horrid muscle spasms, and the next few months none. Some months I can tolerate different foods, such as bread and pasta, and the next month I need to be within 10 feet of a bathroom if I have certain foods. Some months I have a minor headache for the whole month, start a new bottle and no headache. I have shared this with the Tykerb pharmacist and I get the feeling that they think I am crazy. Thanks to all the gals that got me settled into being able to tolerate this drug! Even the oncologist at MDA is wonderfully surprised at the lack of progression and my continued affair with NED. Thinking back to when they told me that I only could wish for weeks, maybe a couple of months - TWO YEARS ago! It was worth it to keep trying to tolerate this drug, THANKS to BCO girls for getting me through!

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 01:58AM - edited Apr 21, 2011 01:59AM by scuttlers Jenn3, You may want to file FMLA, then file for the three disability. My LTD through the employer had a "clause" that I had to be "working" (was still an employee) when the claim was filed. Thank goodness I had really read the policy through! I filed FMLA with the Oncologist stating that I could work 4 hours per week. (this gave me a full paycheck for the 12 weeks FMLA and used up my accumulated sick time.). Then the same week I filed the SSDI, STD, and the LTD. The SSDI was approved within 2 weeks which started my waiting period immediately. The STD was approved and started payment the week my full checks were done. The LTD Insurance called and "verified" that I was still employed when the papers were filed and those payments started the week my STD was finished. (I would have been extremely upset if I had "resigned" and then filed and been denied the LTD! (they told me even one day after resignation would disqualify)

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2015 05:45PM scuttlers wrote: leelee38 - just wanted to let you know that I am an IBC patient also. And just entered my seventh year since diagnosis. Currently I am NED (no evidence of disease) and actually have a good life. It is not my "old life" by any stretch of the imagination, it is my "new normal". I loved my old life and I miss it BUT I can honestly say that my new life is good. IBC scared the crap out of me. I was ready to die. (And in some of the treatments, I really thought I was going to.). BUT I made it through and have had three years of a good relationship with NED. (I had affairs with him the first for years, but they usually only lasted about six months. I think he was checking me out and decided to make it permanent. LOL. I can hold on to that for awhile.). Treatment never stops, so life is arranged around treatment schedules. I can LIVE with that. Giving you an IBC perspective.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2012 12:14PM scuttlers wrote: When I moved to another State, I "interviewed" centers and Oncologist's. I let them know my diagnosis and a short synopsis of my treatments and progress/progression. Then I spoke with the Oncologist's nurses and told them I was interviewing for a good fit. Made it clear that if the onc was not knowledgable about my diagnosis (IBC) and was not willing to discuss my case with me to my satisfaction, and most important the onc had to be willing to work with "experts" of my choosing (my MDA team). I told them that my current treatments would be about $10-17,000 per month in "business" for them. I found a Center and an Oncologist which met my expectations completely. (took a couple of weeks and 5 "consultations"). Once I chose one, I transferred my records. It was worth the time and effort. I was to the point in my insurance plan where they covered 100%, so had no issues on paying for the consultations I have been with my new Center for 18+ months now. They are a smaller center, and have been awesome! I can be seen within hours when I have a problem. My onc works very well with my MDA team (knows them all by their first names!). In other words - I was more concerned with my acceptance of them than of their acceptance of me.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2012 03:25AM scuttlers wrote: Oh Peggy, just so sorry you are having these situations. Wish we could say some magic words and make it all better. Try to make sure she gets lots of liquids, sleep is good. My DH would set a plethora of fluids by my lazy boy. Club soda, Mountain Dew, water, apple juice, pedialite, prune juice, and several teas. He would put straws in them to make it easy to drink. And replace them every hour or so. (some were wasted, but some were drank which was the goal). It put in fluids which forced me to get up for the restroom. As soon as I moved for that, he had warm wet washcloths to wipe me down, and clean underwear and clean shift to put on. He was an absolute GOD during those days. Long story short - FLUIDS, lots of them! Bathroom - make sure kidneys are working. SLEEP - the body is trying to heal and fix. Clean - to help patient feel like living. (((hugs)))

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2012 06:12PM scuttlers wrote: I am also 5'6" and was close to 200#. Although my body was seemingly well proportioned. No belly (due to DIEP). My docs have never said a word UNTIL I (on my own) started a determined effort to get back into shape. (I had traveled so far down as to be in a wheelchair if I had to go very far.) Ate well, but cut out some foods. (breads, pastas, etc.) started walking as much as I could (In 15 minute increments.). And lost almost 20 pounds. The next appointment, the doctor was all over "why are you losing weight? We don't want you to be losing weight right now. (I was on a new chemo, and they thought it was the chemo...) I had to strongly let him know that I was eating right and moving more, my decision, my choice. Started swimming last week and am up to 20 laps in the Olympic pool. I can see my waist! Swimming suit is getting baggy. It is going to be an interesting appointment next week. Don't know how much I've lost, but the body and mind is in a better place. And I am hoping that the doc can see the benefits of this and what it has done to improve my life. Just wanted to let you know that in 3 and 1/2 years not one doctor felt weight loss and muscle tone was important enough to discuss.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 07:05PM scuttlers wrote: I do not believe Medicare covers prescriptions, but you need to have a Medicare Part D (prescription plan) or a Medicare Part C which includes prescription coverage. It is important to check these supplemental plans for coverage that you need PRIOR to signing up with them. There is a page on the Medicare.Gov site where you can put in your zip code to find the plans available in your area. Then you need to input your drugs to see if they are covered and HOW they are covered. (I have also put in ANY and ALL drugs that may be possibly prescribed in the future to see how they are covered.) and VERY IMPORTANT, check with all your healthcare providers to see if they will continue to see you if you sign with a specific plan. (DO NOT believe the company, check directly with the healthcare provider!) YES, I agree, this is absolutely the last thing we should be spending our energies on. We have enough to worry about without this crap. But unfortunately, it is necessary to cover our own bases before making the decision of how to cover our medical expenses as we move into Medicare. I do not know which/what you are using as your supplemental. I am hoping my DH's insurance will be accepted as my secondary (I go on Medicare in September). I do know that GSK has a great program, Tykerb Cares, that helps with the cost. (for me, they dropped my co-pay to $25 per month). I am really hopeful for you that the providers for Xeloda will have a similar program. Tykerb is also provided through the specialty pharmacy. They did require all that information before putting me on the schedule for shipments. My co-pay in July was OVER $2,700, the care program was not retroactive. So please get it in place before setting up shipment. Just found out my insurance Cobra's (primary and secondary) are now very close to $1,400 PER MONTH! (will move to Medicare in Sept.). Not sure how we are going to do this until then. Anyone know of any foundations that help with Cobra?

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 03:41PM scuttlers wrote: I was sailing along, on a beautiful sailboat. The water was beautiful. My life was everything I wanted it to be. My dreams had all come true. My loved ones were all there and we were laughing and enjoying life. We visited wonderful ports and had fun. Then this storm threw me over. It rained and lightening was all around. I knew there were sharks, and barracudas, and other deadly creatures just beyond my sight. My DH had a raft, and he would pull me in and hold me. I would feel safe for awhile, but somehow I always end up back in the water, alone. I have been in those storm and danger filled waters for a long time. Every once in a while I get on another boat or raft. Each chemo, each radiation zap, each surgery has tied another weight around me. I can't get them off. And when I least expect it, the storms come back. It is always dark, I don't see them coming. DH cries out for me, and for a minutes I can be in his arms and feel safe. But then the storm pushes his raft further away. I want to stay with him. Sometimes there are others there, my grand babies, my daughters. My loved ones. They don't know how to keep me in the raft. There is a rope with a huge anchor that always pulls me out of their arms and back into the hostile sea. Alone and crying. Each time I am dragged back into the sea - I vomit, I'm cold, the unseen creatures keep eating my hair off, and scaring my body. I am bloated. The pain is always there. And I get more and more tired of trying to swim and stay afloat. But I know that just over the next wave DH will see me again and pull me in and I'll feel safe and warm and loved for a little while longer. So I keep swimming like mad, just to have one more hour, one more day, one more month, in his arms. Until one day, I just won't be able to make it to the raft one more time.

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2013 05:44PM scuttlers wrote: I raised two girls and did not know quite how to relate to boys. My DH's son was graduating from boot camp (Airforce) and we flew in for graduation. His ex wife also came. We rented a 14 passenger van and took group to the pizza parlor in town. My DH had gone to the next room to order and left me (and ex wife) with the young men. I started telling a story about my brothers that I thought would interest them and they were ALL totally riveted on my every word. I was feeling good, like maybe I was actually connecting. Until ex wife leaned over and told me my dress had unbuttoned. When I took my coat off, my front snaps had popped all the way to my waste. I had chosen that night to wear my beautiful bright red Victoria's Secret wonder bra. Oh my, not one of them had heard a word I said! DH came back to a table of silence. And the next day his son told him that the guys were "impressed" with his step moms glorious TA TA 's. I am still embarrassed to this day! And those "tata's" have been gone for four years ...

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2010 01:55PM scuttlers wrote: Thank you all for the responses.  You have given me the courage to try again.  I spoke with my local oncologist yesterday.  He seemed to understand and is willing to let me try some changes.   I believe the main issue is that I felt there would be no end to the side effects; that I was going to take this drug until it stopped working, and that the side effects would continue.  With the other treatments, there was an end time given; and I knew that if I made it through "one more day", "one more hour", just "one more week" etc. that it would be "over".   I will post as to if the changes help.  (I apologize to those who received multiple sendings of private messages, I am learning for this forum - and when the post didn't immediately send, I clicked send again.  So sorry.)  I am going to start by changing the time of day, and my diet. So today starting day two of back on; and woke up without the dreaded dizziness and nausea.  So far, so good!
Posts.Title: TYKERB - side effects - HELP! scuttlers chainsawz

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2010 11:55PM - edited Aug 3, 2010 11:55PM by scuttlers Well, been taking the Tykerb now EVERY DAY for a month.  SE are totally tolerable! THANKS TO EVERYONE! BUT - - - There are a couple of very weird things going on... First:  I had a loud "hissing" noise in my left ear for about a second and totally lost hearing in that ear.  The hearing loss lasted for almost a week, and about 24 hours after my Herceptin infusion - it suddenly came back.  (No fever, so I don't think it was an infection.) Second:  Twice, I have been driving somewhere and suddenly realize that I am lost.  The first time I was coming home from work, suddenly realized that I did not have a clue as to where I was or how to get home from there.  Thank goodness I have Navigator on my Blackberry!  Today I was headed to one of the clinical sites, and realized that I was about 5 miles from where I was supposed to be headed and going in the wrong direction.  Kind of scared to drive alone now.   Of course, I have a Garmin - - - it was on the kitchen counter.  It will be in the car from now on and programmed before I leave the driveway!  As a side note:  I found the "voice" on the Garmin to be totally irritating - my DH reprogrammed it to a "Scottish" accent - oh my it is so sweet now! Are these episodes common with the Tykerb or should I be hollerin' for my oncologist????

Posts.Content: May 27, 2013 06:22PM scuttlers wrote: Been on this roller coaster since the beginning of 2009. Herceptin from the beginning. Tykerb for the last 3 years. Had progression three times and attacked with some heavy chemos, but kept the Herceptin and Tykerb. TCH, FEC, ACT, Ixempra - there are many in the arsenal to use. The last surgery also showed a change in ER status so Femara was added in. (Biopsies should be done with each progression to check to see if status changes.). It's been tough, but each aggressive treatment got me back to NED. (((HUGS))) to you as you and your team figure out the next step.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2010 10:34AM scuttlers wrote: Welcome to Stage IV, I know you don't want to be here, neither do I.  And it is almost impossible to NOT do the research and see those stupid statistics.  But remember - someone (many someone's) had to be in those 20% or 30% - and I am determined that I will be one of them.  Also, most are calculated on treatment plans that were attempted many years ago.  Treatments are improving, and in a year or two - those numbers are going to be rising.  Finding out what doesn't work is as important as finding out what does work.   ((((HUGS)))) May our journeys be long and full of joy!

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2010 01:29PM scuttlers wrote: Vivo - radical bilateral mastectomy with radical axillary node removal in April 2009.  I am thinking tissue expanders, taking it very slow (radiation changes) up to a year, and then silicone implants.  (I've seen too many bad outcomes from DIEP, Lat Flaps, etc.; remember I work in surgery...) LRM216 - I had no symptoms on the metz.  The onc here in Vegas approved starting reconstruction last November, I requested a PET "just to make sure", and that is when they found the progression. And to all - Thank you for rejoicing with me - and don't give up!  Those docs are only human, they are not God -  and I do not have an expiration date stamp!
